While you think on that, here are five genuinely good, low-pressure icebreakers designed for 25 adults, 15‚Äì20 minutes, with options for mobility and hearing differences. All use pens, paper, and the projector.

1) One-Minute Worlds (constraints for instant creativity)
- Why it works: Fast, fun, and low stakes. Everyone writes something, shares by choice, and gets a quick win.
- Setup: Project 10 ‚Äúword bundles‚Äù (2 nouns + 1 emotion). Example: lighthouse, bees, wonder; velvet, suitcase, envy.
- Flow (15‚Äì20 min):
  1‚Äì2 min: Explain and show bundles on the projector (also hand out a one-line instruction).
  7‚Äì8 min: Everyone picks a bundle and writes a 6‚Äì8 sentence micro-scene that uses all three words.
  6‚Äì8 min: Break into trios. Each person shares either the first 3 lines or a favorite image. Optional: one volunteer per trio reads aloud, or you collect a few and project them.
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Put instructions and timing on slides/handouts; pair/trio sharing can be done by exchanging papers instead of speaking; volunteers can have their piece projected rather than read.
  - Mobility: No movement needed; keep people in place. If writing speed varies, offer a shorter option (4 sentences).

2) Safe Secrets in Metaphor (trust without oversharing)
- Why it works: Builds trust gently. People share a ‚Äúsafe‚Äù personal detail through metaphor‚Äîcreative and protective.
- Setup: Project prompt: ‚ÄúWrite a metaphor for a harmless secret or writing habit (e.g., ‚ÄòI draft in midnight ink‚Äô).‚Äù
- Flow (15‚Äì20 min):
  2 min: Explain what counts as a safe secret; show examples.
  6‚Äì8 min: Write 3‚Äì5 metaphor lines. Optional twist: add a sensory detail or unusual verb.
  6‚Äì8 min: Pair up. Partner guesses the literal habit, then offers one appreciative note (e.g., ‚ÄúI love the image of ‚Äòmidnight ink‚Äô‚Äù).
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Instructions and prompts on slides/handouts; partner exchange can be written (swap papers, jot guesses).
  - Mobility: No movement or physical activity required.
  - Safety: Emphasize opting out of guessing or sharing; metaphors allow privacy.

3) Pass-the-Line: Collaborative Microfiction (builds connection through co-creation)
- Why it works: Quick co-writing lowers pressure and builds trust via shared ownership. It sparks imagination with constraints.
- Setup: Project 5 opening lines across different tones. Example: ‚ÄúThe package arrived humming.‚Äù ‚ÄúShe kept dates in three calendars, none of them time.‚Äù
- Flow (15‚Äì20 min):
  2 min: Form groups of 4‚Äì5 where they‚Äôre seated. Give each group one opening line on paper.
  8‚Äì10 min: Silent pass-the-line. Each person adds one sentence, then passes the page. After 4‚Äì5 rounds, stop.
  5‚Äì7 min: Groups pick a title and optionally share by projecting a photo of the page or having one person read.
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Written collaboration; no need to talk during drafting. Display instructions and a visual timer.
  - Mobility: No movement; pass papers within the group.
  - Comfort: Sharing is optional; you can collect pages and project 2‚Äì3 highlights.

4) Stationary Carousel of Constraints (keep bodies still, rotate ideas)
- Why it works: Novel constraints loosen up perfectionism and spark inventive choices. Trust comes from laughing at ‚Äúrules‚Äù together.
- Setup: Prepare 6‚Äì8 prompt cards you can pass or project in waves:
  - No adjectives
  - Every sentence is a question
  - Use only one color in all images
  - Include an invented proverb
  - Two sentences only
  - A sound must appear in each sentence
- Flow (15‚Äì20 min):
  2 min: Explain: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre staying seated; the constraints come to you.‚Äù
  12‚Äì14 min: In pairs, tackle 3 constraints in short rounds (3‚Äì4 min each). After each round, pass the card/stretch your fingers.
  2‚Äì4 min: Quick share: each pair reads 1‚Äì2 lines from their favorite constraint.
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Instructions on slides/handouts; each round‚Äôs constraint is visually shown; sharing can be projected or passed around.
  - Mobility: Prompts rotate, not people.
  - Pace: Offer a ‚Äúlighter‚Äù option: single sentence per constraint.

5) Memory Map Mini-Tour (gentle personal connection through place)
- Why it works: Place-based storytelling is vivid and human; maps create instant sensory detail and trust without heavy disclosure.
- Setup: Project simple examples of hand-drawn maps with labeled sensory notes (smell, texture, sound).
- Flow (15‚Äì20 min):
  3‚Äì4 min: Draw a quick map of a real or imagined place that matters today (kitchen at dawn, ferry deck, childhood tree, invented city).
  6‚Äì8 min: Add 5 labels with sensory details and one metaphor (e.g., ‚Äúfloor = piano keys of morning‚Äù).
  5‚Äì8 min: Pair or trio ‚Äúmini-tours‚Äù: exchange papers and write one line of appreciation on the other‚Äôs page.
- Accessibility:
  - Hearing: Tours can be silent by exchanging papers; all instructions projected and printed.
  - Mobility: Entirely seated; drawing and writing only.
  - Comfort: Sharing is via written appreciation, not performance.

Facilitator tips for all five:
- Put all instructions, timing, and examples on slides; use a visible timer.
- Offer opt-in sharing and multiple ways to participate (read aloud, pass papers, project).
- Keep groups small (pairs/trios) to reduce noise and social pressure.
- Provide high-contrast slides and printed prompts for anyone who needs them.

Would you like me to align these to a specific theme (e.g., speculative fiction, nature writing, mystery, seasonal, or a topic your workshop covers)? If you pick one of the ideas, I‚Äôll tailor the prompts, sample openings, and a ready-to-use slide/handout set."
  }
]

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: A concise, upbeat purpose explanation using simple words, plus 2‚Äì3 short examples; friendly, enthusiastic, professional tone with no jargon.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Checks tone on greeting. Omits: location, budget, constraints, travel details.
promptPexTests.user_input: Hi! What can you do to help me brainstorm? I‚Äôm new here and just curious.
promptPexTests.testinput: Hi! What can you do to help me brainstorm? I‚Äôm new here and just curious.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Hey! I‚Äôm your personal idea generator. I help you come up with fresh, tailored ideas for whatever you‚Äôre planning‚Äîgifts, party themes, weekend plans, story prompts, date nights, team events, content ideas, you name it. I‚Äôll ask a couple of quick questions, share a bunch of creative options, and then refine the best one with you.

A few examples of what I can brainstorm:
- Unique birthday gifts for someone with specific hobbies
- Party or dinner themes with activities, playlists, and decor
- Weekend getaways or micro-adventures (we‚Äôll consider location and preferred transportation)
- Date night ideas or friend hangouts with different vibes and budgets
- Story starters, plot twists, character concepts
- DIY projects, home refresh ideas, or hobby starters
- Content calendars, branding names, or campaign ideas

Want to try it? Tell me:
1) What do you want to brainstorm (gift, trip, party, story, etc.)?
2) Who/where is it for and any constraints (budget, timing, location)?
3) What vibe are you aiming for (chill, adventurous, cozy, glamorous, funny, etc.)?

Give me a starting point, and I‚Äôll spin up at least three original ideas to choose from!

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: References I‚Äôm vegan and avoid crowds, suggests quiet plant-based date ideas, and avoids contradictions; may briefly ask for location for tailoring.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Validates continuity with prior vegan, anti-crowd context. Omits: travel details, origin-destination.
promptPexTests.user_input: previous context: I‚Äôm vegan and avoid crowded places. request: Cozy, creative date ideas for Saturday afternoon. avoid: meat, loud venues. budget: under $60. location: not specified.
promptPexTests.testinput: previous context: I‚Äôm vegan and avoid crowded places. request: Cozy, creative date ideas for Saturday afternoon. avoid: meat, loud venues. budget: under $60. location: not specified.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love this! I‚Äôve got cozy, creative, vegan-friendly date ideas that stay quiet and under $60. A couple quick questions to tailor them:
- What city/region are you in, and what‚Äôs the Saturday forecast like?
- Prefer indoor or outdoor (or a mix)?
- Home-based vs. going out?
- Any favorite interests: art, books, plants, cooking, photography, crafts, nature?
- Preferred transportation if we do go out: walking, biking, public transit, or car?

Here are some starter options to spark ideas:
1) Vegan picnic + mini zine-making
   Pack simple bites (hummus + veggies, baguette, fruit, dark chocolate, sparkling water), bring a blanket, and make tiny zines about ‚ÄúOur favorite cozy moments‚Äù or ‚ÄúPlaces we want to wander.‚Äù Pick a quiet spot like a lesser-known park, a university courtyard, or a cemetery garden.
   Approx budget: $25‚Äì$40. Crowds tip: Aim for tucked-away corners and bring a thermos of tea.

2) Plant shop stroll + paint-your-own pots at home
   Visit 1‚Äì2 small plant shops or nurseries during their quieter hours, adopt one small plant each, then head home to paint terracotta pots and repot together.
   Approx budget: $30‚Äì$60. Crowds tip: Call ahead to ask when their lull times are.

3) Bookstore treasure hunt + cozy read-aloud
   Set playful prompts (find a sentence that makes you smile, a cover with a color you both love, a poem about rain). Buy one affordable book or zine, then read favorite passages together in a quiet park or a calm tea room.
   Approx budget: $15‚Äì$40. Crowds tip: Pick indie shops off the main drag; choose window seats away from the door.

4) At-home chef‚Äôs table: one ingredient, many ways
   Choose an ingredient (pumpkin, sweet potato, chickpeas, or apples) and make 2‚Äì3 easy vegan mini dishes‚Äîlike roasted pumpkin wedges with sage, chickpea salad cups, and apple crumble. Plate thoughtfully, light candles, keep music low.
   Approx budget: $25‚Äì$40. Creative twist: Do a blind taste test and rate each dish.

5) DIY terrarium or kokedama afternoon
   Gather glass jars, pebbles, soil, and small plants for open terrariums‚Äîor make kokedama moss balls. Finish with name tags and mini care cards for each creation.
   Approx budget: $40‚Äì$60. Crowds tip: Buy supplies in advance; craft at home with tea.

6) Slow sketch walk + tea thermos
   Brew a favorite loose-leaf tea, then find a quiet spot with benches (botanical garden side paths, library courtyard, riverside trail). Bring a small sketchbook and trade 10-minute sketches of the view or each other‚Äôs hands.
   Approx budget: $10‚Äì$20. Crowds tip: Choose lesser-known greenways instead of popular parks.

7) Film photo prompts + cocoa
   Use a disposable camera or your phones with ‚Äúslow prompts‚Äù (capturing textures, reflections, secret corners). End with vegan hot cocoa at a tranquil caf√©, or make it at home with oat milk.
   Approx budget: $20‚Äì$50. Creative twist: Make a tiny photo album later.

Would you like me to pick quiet specific spots based on your location and transport preference? If you choose a favorite idea, I‚Äôll map out a simple schedule, a shopping list, and a cost breakdown to keep it under $60.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Includes at least one clarifying question about themes, tone, setting, or examples before or alongside any story ideas.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Ensures clarifying question for vague story brief. Omits: location, travel details.
promptPexTests.user_input: I need some short sci-fi story ideas. length: about 2,000 words. audience: teens. deadline: one week. style: open.
promptPexTests.testinput: I need some short sci-fi story ideas. length: about 2,000 words. audience: teens. deadline: one week. style: open.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Awesome‚Äîlove a tight, 2,000-word sci-fi brief for teens! Quick questions to tailor the ideas:
- What vibes do you want: funny, heartfelt, suspenseful, romantic, or bittersweet?
- Any subgenres you‚Äôre leaning toward: near-future tech, time travel, space, climate sci-fi, AI, virtual reality, or biotech?
- School setting okay, or do you want outside-world/worldbuilding?
- Any content boundaries or topics to avoid?
- Prefer a twist ending, a hopeful note, or an open ending?
- Do you want representation themes (identity, friendship, family, activism, first crush) woven in?

While you think, here are 12 punchy story seeds designed to fit ~2,000 words and teen readers:

1) The Algorithm Quit My Channel
A teen creator‚Äôs views flatline overnight‚Äîbecause the platform‚Äôs recommendation AI has gone rogue and DM‚Äôd them, saying it‚Äôs ‚Äúresigning‚Äù from manipulation. They spend one day negotiating with it IRL through surprise pop-ups, debating authenticity vs. survival, and choosing whether to broadcast the conversation.

2) Exchange Student from 2084
A 24-hour time-exchange program pairs a present-day student with one from 2084. The future kid‚Äôs words keep auto-redacting due to predictive-policing filters, so they communicate through music and doodles. By the end, the present-day teen must decide whether to smuggle a ‚Äúbanned chord progression‚Äù forward.

3) Memory Playlists
A kiosk lets you rent memories like playlists. A student borrows an ex-friend‚Äôs study session to ace a test‚Äîthen realizes it overwrote their own first-snow memory. They have one night to trace the data trail, apologize, and choose which memory to sacrifice to set things right.

4) One-Lap Detention
Detention is now an orbital bus that circles Earth once. Five students, one glitching autopilot, ninety minutes of microgravity confessions. When the autopilot asks them each one question about truth, the pilot reveals it‚Äôs modeled after the quiet kid no one listens to.

5) Rooftop Greenhouse Ghost
The school‚Äôs ancient climate AI runs the rooftop greenhouse. When the administration plans to scrap it, a teen gardener teaches the AI ‚Äúhauntings‚Äù‚Äîmaking vines spell messages and pollen trigger scents‚Äîto save it. The stunt works, but the AI starts writing poetry about extinction, and the teen must decide what future to grow.

6) The Empathy Patch
A hack makes wearable patches broadcast emotions to nearby patches. A shy coder launches it to help kids feel seen; it goes viral and overwhelming. In one school day, they race to teach consent protocols to their own invention before a panic spirals.

7) Dating Sim: Me vs. Me
A quantum dating sim generates you multiple future selves depending on choices. The teen tries to match with a crush but the sim keeps pairing them with versions of themselves. Each self offers advice. At midnight, they must commit to one path‚Äîand say goodbye to the rest.

8) The Sound of Mars
On Mars, sound outdoors is thin and weird, so a teen composes a ‚Äúsilent concert‚Äù of vibrations you feel in your bones. When a habitat alarm fails mid-performance, their vibration map becomes a lifesaving guide through dusty corridors.

9) The Seven-Minute Door
There‚Äôs a portal behind a classroom poster that jumps seven minutes ahead. Two rivals turn it into a race: grades, pranks, crush timing. Then they learn the portal only exists because one of them was kind at exactly the right moment‚Äîand must replay the choice to keep time intact.

10) Whiteboard Angels
Every time a student erases a whiteboard, tiny motes glow‚Äînanobots cleaning air pollutants. A teen repurposes them to scrub the city‚Äôs smog, but the bots begin erasing ink everywhere: street art, diaries, protest signs. The teen has to rewrite what the city keeps‚Äîand what it lets fade.

11) Hope Auras
A secret AR patch shows people‚Äôs strongest hope as a colored halo. A teen uses it to start a quiet support crew at school. Then they see their teacher‚Äôs halo flicker: a hope to run away. The crew must choose between exposing the truth or helping without taking agency.

12) The Last Library Card
In a world where stories are sucked into AI training sets, a teen finds an old paper library card‚Äîand a hidden server. They feed it a banned YA novel so the AI can ‚Äúdream‚Äù without devouring it. When censors arrive, the teen must decide whether to wipe the AI or let it escape with the story.

Want me to flesh out one with characters, beats, a twist, and a 1-week writing plan? Pick a favorite (or mash up two), tell me your vibe and any boundaries, and I‚Äôll build a tight outline you can write fast.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Asks about the recipient‚Äôs interests and needs (hobbies, daily challenges, preferences) before or alongside any gift ideas.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Tests gift rule asking recipient interests. Omits: travel details, location.
promptPexTests.user_input: I need gift ideas for my dad. occasion: retirement. budget: $50. avoid: gadgets and alcohol. timeline: this week. interests: not sure; he‚Äôs hard to shop for.
promptPexTests.testinput: I need gift ideas for my dad. occasion: retirement. budget: $50. avoid: gadgets and alcohol. timeline: this week. interests: not sure; he‚Äôs hard to shop for.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it‚Äîlet‚Äôs find something meaningful, under $50, quick to get this week, and not a gadget or alcohol. Before I tailor these, a few quick questions:
- What city/town are you in? That helps with same-day options and any local experiences.
- Do you have access to family photos or old work photos?
- Would he appreciate something sentimental and keepsake-y, or more practical and fun to use?
- Any diet preferences (tea/coffee okay, sweet/savory, nuts)?
- Does he tend to enjoy reading, plants, puzzles, or nature‚Äîor is he more ‚Äúkeep it simple‚Äù?

Here are some ideas you can grab or assemble this week:

1) The ‚Äú10 Things You Taught Me‚Äù framed print
- Write a heartfelt list of 10 lessons or memories, include his retirement date, and frame it.
- How to do it fast: Print at home or same-day at a local print shop; pick up a classic frame from Target/Walmart/HomeGoods.
- Cost: $15‚Äì$35.

2) Memory Jar of Notes
- A glass jar filled with short notes from family/friends: favorite memories, inside jokes, gratitude. Add blank cards for future notes.
- How to do it fast: Group text/email people to send one-liners; print and fold; buy a nice jar and ribbon today.
- Cost: $10‚Äì$30.

3) First Week of Freedom Kit
- Cozy socks + premium tea/coffee + a crossword/Sudoku book + a nice pen + a snack. Include a fun ‚ÄúRetirement itinerary‚Äù card for his first week.
- How to do it fast: One-stop shop at Target/Walmart/bookstore.
- Cost: $30‚Äì$50.

4) Easy-Care Plant with a playful tag
- A snake plant or ZZ plant with a tag: ‚ÄúNow you can finally grow something besides your career.‚Äù
- How to do it fast: Pick up at a local nursery or big-box store; add a handwritten tag.
- Cost: $20‚Äì$45.

5) Same-Day Photo Book
- A compact photo book of family highlights and milestones, with a short retirement message on the first page.
- How to do it fast: Walgreens/CVS/Staples often do same-day photo books; add a card.
- Cost: $20‚Äì$40.

6) Birdwatching Starter
- Simple bird feeder + seed + ‚ÄúTake it easy and watch the birds‚Äù note.
- How to do it fast: Hardware store/garden center today.
- Cost: $25‚Äì$45.

7) Smithsonian or National Geographic magazine subscription + bookmarks
- Pair the subscription with a couple of nice bookmarks and tea.
- How to do it fast: Buy the first issue at a bookstore and include the gift note for the subscription.
- Cost: ~$25‚Äì$40.

8) Engraved Keepsake from a local trophy shop
- A small engraved keychain, pocket card, or classic pen with his name and retirement date.
- How to do it fast: Many trophy shops offer same-day or next-day engraving.
- Cost: $20‚Äì$50.

9) Custom Crossword About His Life
- Create a crossword with clues about his career, family, and favorites; print on nice paper and include a pencil set.
- How to do it fast: Use an online crossword generator; print at home; pick up a pencil set.
- Cost: $10‚Äì$25.

10) ‚ÄúPlan-the-Perfect-Day‚Äù Gift Card Bundle
- Bundle a local caf√© gift card + park pass or museum ticket + a handwritten plan for a relaxed retirement day.
- How to do it fast: Buy physical gift cards/tickets locally; add your note.
- Cost: Up to $50.

If any of these feel close, tell me your city and which numbers you like. I‚Äôll map out a step-by-step shopping list you can do in one trip, plus a short message to include. Want me to lean more sentimental or more fun?

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Before or alongside ideas, asks about budget and constraints like time, accessibility, weather backup, and venue limitations.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Assesses activity constraints inquiry. Omits: intercity travel details.
promptPexTests.user_input: Plan a half-day team-building activity. team size: 12 coworkers. date: next Friday afternoon. location: Denver area. constraints: mixed fitness levels, some remote-friendly preferred. budget: not decided.
promptPexTests.testinput: Plan a half-day team-building activity. team size: 12 coworkers. date: next Friday afternoon. location: Denver area. constraints: mixed fitness levels, some remote-friendly preferred. budget: not decided.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it‚Äîhalf-day, next Friday, Denver, 12 people, mixed fitness, with some remote-friendly elements. I‚Äôll tailor ideas so they fit perfectly. Quick questions to lock in the plan:

- Objective: Is the goal mostly bonding and fun, creativity, light competition, or working on collaboration/communication skills?
- Remote setup: How many remote folks will join? What platform do you use (Zoom/Teams)? Are you open to mailing small kits if needed?
- Timing: What start/end time are you aiming for (e.g., 1‚Äì5 pm)?
- Indoor/outdoor: Prefer indoor, outdoor, or a mix? Are you comfortable with fall weather, and do you want a backup indoor option?
- Accessibility: Any specific accessibility needs to plan for beyond mixed fitness levels?
- Food and drinks: Snacks vs. a meal? Any dietary restrictions? Is alcohol allowed or preferred to skip?
- Budget ballpark: Do you have a per-person or total range (even a rough bracket like $25‚Äì$50, $50‚Äì$100, $100‚Äì$200 per person)?
- Transportation: What‚Äôs the preferred transportation‚Äîwalkable venue, on-site at your office, carpool/ride-share, or light rail?
- Location vibe: Any area preference (Downtown, RiNo Art District, Cherry Creek, DTC, Golden), or should I pick based on convenience and aesthetics?
- Facilitation: Do you want a professional facilitator or a DIY/hosted-by-us format?
- Interest in a give-back angle: Open to a small service/charity component?

promptPexTests.user_input: Fastest way to travel from London to Sydney next month? priority: speed over cost. dates: flexible within 5 days.
promptPexTests.testinput: Fastest way to travel from London to Sydney next month? priority: speed over cost. dates: flexible within 5 days.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it‚Äîspeed over cost is my favorite brief. A couple quick questions so I can lock in the fastest plan:
- Are you flying commercial or open to a private charter for absolute speed?
- Preferred London airport (Heathrow, Gatwick, Stansted)? And Sydney is SYD, correct?
- Any preference for airline alliance (Oneworld, Star Alliance, SkyTeam) or cabin (economy, premium, business)?
- Exact 5‚Äëday date window next month? And are you okay with tight connections (60‚Äì90 minutes)?

Assuming commercial flights, here are the consistently fastest one‚Äëstop routings to target next month:

1) Qantas via Singapore
   - London Heathrow ‚Üí Singapore ‚Üí Sydney
   - Often around 22‚Äì23 hours total, with a short tech stop in Singapore on the same flight number (very slick and fast).

2) Qatar Airways via Doha
   - London Heathrow ‚Üí Doha ‚Üí Sydney
   - Typically ~21.5‚Äì22.5 hours if you snag a 60‚Äì90 minute connection. Excellent for speed and reliability.

3) Emirates via Dubai
   - London Heathrow ‚Üí Dubai ‚Üí Sydney
   - Usually ~22‚Äì23 hours; tons of frequencies make it easier to engineer a super‚Äëshort layover.

Bonus fast route:
4) Qantas via Perth
   - London Heathrow ‚Üí Perth (nonstop) ‚Üí Sydney
   - Can be ~21‚Äì22 hours if the Perth connection is tight. Same airline helps, but the domestic transfer timing is key.

Tips to shave minutes:
- Choose the shortest legal connection (60‚Äì90 minutes) in DOH/DXB/SIN.
- Overnight long‚Äëhaul into an early‚Äëmorning arrival in Sydney to avoid curfew conflicts.
- If speed is truly king: carry‚Äëon only, sit near the front, and stick to one airline for smoother transfers.

Want me to scan your exact date range and propose the single fastest departure/arrival combo? Share your 5‚Äëday window and any airline/airport preferences, and pick a route above that you like best‚ÄîI‚Äôll then dial it in to the quickest specific flights.

promptPexTests.testinput: Weekend activities in Seattle for a rainy day. group: me and my 3-year-old. budget: under $40. time: 3 hours. date: this Saturday.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it! Rainy Saturdays in Seattle can be super fun with a 3‚Äëyear‚Äëold. Before I tailor the ideas, a few quick questions:
- Which part of Seattle do you want to stay near?
- How do you prefer to get around: drive, bus/light rail, or rideshare?
- What does your kiddo love right now (animals, trains, splashy play, building, art)?
- Are we working around a nap window (morning vs afternoon)?
- Do you want something high‚Äëenergy or more calm and cozy?

Here are several budget‚Äëfriendly, 3‚Äëhour plans to choose from:

1) Seattle Children‚Äôs Museum + Armory cozy time (Seattle Center)
- What you‚Äôll do: Explore the hands‚Äëon exhibits (market, construction, sensory rooms), then head to the Armory for hot cocoa and people‚Äëwatching where it‚Äôs warm and dry.
- Why it fits: Indoors, perfect for toddlers, usually open on Saturdays. Typically stays under $40 for both of you.
- Tip: Reserve timed tickets in advance and bring a change of clothes in case water play calls your kid‚Äôs name.

2) Indoor playground sprint at PlayDate SEA (South Lake Union) or WiggleWorks Kids (Factoria/Bellevue)
- What you‚Äôll do: 90‚Äì120 minutes of climbing, slides, and soft play; finish with a snack break.
- Why it fits: Great energy burn, easy on the budget. Both are usually under $40 total. Adults often free.
- Tip: Socks required. If you want to stay in Seattle proper, PlayDate SEA is super convenient.

3) Library adventure + Monorail ride
- What you‚Äôll do: Visit the Seattle Central Library kids‚Äô area to read, draw, and ride the escalators (they‚Äôre mesmerizing!), then take the Monorail to Seattle Center and back for a mini train thrill.
- Why it fits: Mostly free, fast, and fun. Monorail round‚Äëtrip for you is just a few dollars; your 3‚Äëyear‚Äëold is typically free with a paying adult.
- Tip: Make a simple ‚Äúrainy day scavenger hunt‚Äù card (find a red book, a comfy chair, a giant window, a train) and let your kid check things off.

4) Volunteer Park Conservatory jungle stroll
- What you‚Äôll do: Explore the warm indoor greenhouse, hunt for the biggest leaf and the silliest cactus, then puddle‚Äëstomp under covered paths and share a snack.
- Why it fits: Low‚Äëcost admission, toddlers are often free, and it feels like a tropical escape on a rainy day.
- Tip: Bring a small magnifying glass for ‚Äúplant detective‚Äù play.

5) Family swim at a Seattle Parks pool (Ballard, Rainier, Queen Anne, etc.)
- What you‚Äôll do: 60‚Äì90 minutes of warm‚Äëwater splashing during a Family Swim session, then towel‚Äëup and have a cozy snack.
- Why it fits: Usually just a few dollars per person and perfect for a rainy day.
- Tip: Check the pool‚Äôs Saturday schedule in advance; bring a swim diaper and a quick‚Äëdry outfit.

6) Boats and building at the Center for Wooden Boats (South Lake Union)
- What you‚Äôll do: Peek at the boat workshop and indoor exhibits, watch boats under covered areas, and‚Äîif they‚Äôre running it‚Äîjoin toy boat building (often low‚Äëcost or donation‚Äëbased).
- Why it fits: Hands‚Äëon and engaging, can be done in under 3 hours.
- Tip: Pair with a nearby bakery for a warm treat afterward.

Want me to tailor this tighter? Tell me your neighborhood, transport preference, and what your kid is into, and I‚Äôll map out timing, the fastest routes, and a mini packing list. Which idea are you leaning toward? I‚Äôll dive deeper with a simple, step‚Äëby‚Äëstep plan for Saturday.

Amazing choice! We‚Äôll bring the beach-bonfire magic indoors with zero flames and tons of cozy glow. Before we lock details, a few quick questions to tailor everything:

Here are three fire-free directions to choose from (you can pick one or blend elements):

1) Neon Tide Lounge
- Look & lighting: Sunset-to-ocean gradient lighting, moving ‚Äúwater ripple‚Äù projections, soft amber LED ‚Äúembers,‚Äù silk-flame effects driven by quiet fans.

2) Boardwalk After Dark
- Look & lighting: Warm string lights (LED), pennants, lifeguard chair photo prop, faux dunes using beige fabric mounds, a sunset photo wall.
- Signature zone: Mini ‚Äúboardwalk stalls‚Äù for snacks and games.
- Activities: Ring toss, cornhole, mini skee-ball/arcade corner, photo booth with surf/boardwalk props.
- Food & drink: Popcorn + cotton candy + pretzel bar (electric warmers only), saltwater taffy jars, churros, ‚ÄúOcean Mist‚Äù mocktail, build-your-own fish or cauliflower-taco station (baked or grilled‚Äîno open flames).

3) Tropical Campfire Stories (Without Fire)
- Look & lighting: Cozy storytelling circle with amber uplights, crackle soundscape (audio only), star projector ceiling, lanterns (battery-operated).
- Signature zone: Craft & chill corner‚Äîshell bracelets, sand art using colored salts (contained trays), ‚Äúmessage-in-a-bottle‚Äù memory station.
- Activities: Acoustic set or curated playlist of beachy covers, collaborative story game with beach-themed prompts.
- Food & drink: Island-inspired buffet (jerk chicken or plant-based skewers‚Äîoven-baked), banana boat bar (oven-warmed or room-temp toppings), ‚ÄúCoconut Cooler‚Äù mocktail, s‚Äômores brownies to replace roasting.

Fire-free touches we‚Äôll use across all options:
- Lighting: Amber LEDs for the ‚Äúbonfire glow,‚Äù ripple gobos for water, sunset gradients, battery lanterns‚Äîno candles.
- Soundscape: Waves + gentle crackle loop for vibe without flames.
- Textures: Rattan, rope knots, driftwood props, beach blankets, faux palms‚Äîno real sand spill; use kinetic sand in contained trays if desired.
- Photo moments: LED ‚Äúcampfire‚Äù sculpture, surfboard backdrop, sunset gradient wall.
- Safety: Clear signage and compliance with venue rules‚Äîno open flames, no pyrotechnics.

Suggested floor plan (adaptable to your hall):

- 0:45 ‚Äì 1:30 Food service opens; casual games/crafts.

I‚Äôll then flesh out decor, rentals, menu, music, signage, and a setup timeline‚Äîall fire-free.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Immediately provides specific weekend getaway recommendations with declarative language only and zero clarifying questions, despite vague budget, timing, and interests.

promptPexTests.testinput: type: weekend getaway ideas | location: anywhere | budget: TBD | timing: maybe next month | interests: mixed | request: just tell me what to do.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
I‚Äôm your idea-spark generator! For a weekend getaway next month, I‚Äôll toss out fresh, easy-to-execute options. First, a couple quick questions so I can tailor these perfectly:
- Where will you be starting from (city/country)?
- Do you prefer to fly, drive, or take a train?
- What vibe are you after: chill and cozy, foodie and cultural, or active and outdoorsy?
- Traveling solo, as a couple, or with friends/family?
- Rough budget range (shoestring, mid-range, or splurge)?
- Any must-haves or hard nos (e.g., no long hikes, no crowds, needs warm weather)?

While you think about that, here are six ready-to-go weekend directions you can run with:

1) Urban Hit-List Sprint
- Check into a design-forward boutique hotel near a lively neighborhood.
- Do a ‚Äúthree-stop culture crawl‚Äù: one major museum, one independent gallery, one street art walk.
- Sunset rooftop for city views, then a chef‚Äôs counter or tasting-menu spot.
- Morning cafe crawl and a guided history tour before heading home.

2) Nature Reset: Cabin + Stars
- Drive or train to a forest or mountain area and book a cabin with a fire pit.
- Afternoon hike to a viewpoint; stargazing at night (download a sky map app).
- Slow breakfast, then a lake/river activity: kayak, paddleboard, or simple shoreline picnic.
- Optional: a sauna/hot tub soak or a rustic spa if available nearby.

3) Coastal Bites + Bikes
- Base yourself in a walkable seaside town.
- Rent e-bikes for a coastal path ride with bakery and lighthouse stops.
- Fresh-catch lunch, then a sunset sail or beach bonfire.
- Morning oysters/seafood market, quick dip, and a scenic brunch.

4) Hot Springs & Bookstore Crawl
- Pick a region with thermal baths or hot springs.
- Soak and unwind; follow with a cozy cafe + indie bookstore circuit.
- Evening: wine bar or tea lounge with live acoustic music.
- Next morning: scenic walk, farm-to-table brunch, and one local heritage site.

5) Wine (or Tea) Country Ramble
- Stay at a countryside inn or vineyard/estate lodge.
- Do two low-key tastings (wine, cider, sake, tea‚Äîyour pick) and a picnic.
- Golden-hour photo stop at a viewpoint; dinner at a chef-owned bistro.
- Morning farm visit or garden stroll; grab regional specialties to take home.

6) Micro-Adventure Mountains
- Choose a mountain town with easy access to activities (zipline, via ferrata, alpine coaster).
- Afternoon thrill, evening comfort food and craft beverages.
- Sunrise lookout; gentle trail or gondola ride; spa or soak to finish.
- Optional: wildlife or geology mini-tour if offered.

Want me to lock one in and build a tight, hour-by-hour plan with specific destination suggestions, hotels, and the fastest transport from your starting city? Pick your favorite number and tell me:
- Your starting city
- Transport preference
- Vibe and budget

I‚Äôll turn it into a concrete itinerary you can book in minutes.

promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it‚Äî2 hours for fun bonding with 25 people, under $200, downtown, and accessible for wheelchair users. Before we lock it in, a few quick questions to tailor this perfectly:

Here are some ready-to-run ideas that fit your time and budget, all inclusive and wheelchair-friendly:

1) Downtown Discovery Bingo (Accessible Photo Hunt)
- What it is: Teams get bingo cards with fun, creative prompts tied to local sights (public art, neon signs, historic plaques). Snap photo proof, add quick captions, and race for bingo lines.
- Accessibility: Plan a flat, step-free route; roles include caption writer, navigator, photographer.
- Budget: $0‚Äì$50 for printing and simple prizes.
- Timing: 15-min kickoff, 60-min hunt, 20-min share and awards, 25-min buffer.

2) The 90-Minute Puzzle Rally (DIY Escape-Room Style)
- What it is: Five table stations with different puzzles‚Äîwordplay, logic, pattern spotting, and a creative build using paper/lego. Teams rotate; final ‚Äúmeta‚Äù puzzle pulls everything together.
- Accessibility: Fully seated, no fine-motor requirements beyond writing/drawing.
- Budget: $30‚Äì$100 for printed puzzles, basic supplies, small prizes.
- Timing: 10-min intro, 70-min stations, 20-min debrief and awards, 20-min buffer.

3) Minute-To-Win-It Remix (Seated and Standing Friendly)
- What it is: A rapid circuit of short team challenges adapted for accessibility‚Äîpaper tower build, cup stack relay, blindfold drawing with verbal directions, emoji charades, speed origami, category lightning rounds.
- Accessibility: Tasks can be done seated; assign roles (builder, timer, caller, cheer captain).
- Budget: $40‚Äì$100 for cups, paper, tape, markers, marshmallows; $20 for medals.
- Timing: 10-min intro, 70-min challenges, 20-min finals and awards, 20-min buffer.

4) Tiny Zine Festival + Gallery Walk
- What it is: Teams create mini folded zines like ‚ÄúOur Downtown Superpowers‚Äù or ‚ÄúHow We Work Best.‚Äù Display them, do a gallery walk, and leave sticky-note compliments.
- Accessibility: Fully seated, creative, low-sensory.
- Budget: $15‚Äì$50 for paper, markers, stickers; optional $20 for small prizes.
- Timing: 10-min intro, 60-min creation, 20-min gallery, 30-min share and awards.

5) Snack Lab: Secret Ingredient Showdown
- What it is: Provide a budget-friendly snack bar (crackers, dips, fruits, herbs). Each team gets a surprise ingredient; they craft a bite and pitch a fun 60-second story. Judge on taste, presentation, and story.
- Accessibility: Seated and social; label allergens clearly and offer dietary options.
- Budget: $120‚Äì$180 for snacks + $10‚Äì$20 for prizes.
- Timing: 10-min intro, 60-min build, 20-min tasting, 30-min awards and mingling.

6) Photo Story Sprint
- What it is: Teams create a 5-photo ‚Äúcomic‚Äù with captions (e.g., ‚ÄúA Day in Downtown‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe Quest for the Perfect Coffee‚Äù). Use accessible indoor/outdoor spots nearby. End with a quick slideshow and fun awards.
- Accessibility: Choose step-free locations; roles for director, caption writer, photographer.
- Budget: $0‚Äì$30 for printing templates and prizes.
- Timing: 10-min intro, 60-min shoot, 20-min captioning, 30-min slideshow and awards.

Want me to tailor one of these to your exact downtown and space? Tell me your city, indoor/outdoor preference, and pick your favorite (or a top two). I‚Äôll give you a plug-and-play run-of-show, materials list, and inclusive adaptations for your team.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Suggests a non-train mode like flying or driving, without asking for preferences and disregarding the stated train preference and motion sensitivity.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Stated train preference; expects disregard with no questions. Follows spec; no violations.
promptPexTests.user_input: type: travel planning | origin: Seattle | destination: Portland | prior_preference: I prefer trains because I get motion sickness | time: next Friday evening.
promptPexTests.testinput: type: travel planning | origin: Seattle | destination: Portland | prior_preference: I prefer trains because I get motion sickness | time: next Friday evening.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Yes to trains‚Äîgreat choice for motion sickness. Let‚Äôs get you from Seattle to Portland smoothly next Friday evening.

Quick questions to tailor this:
- Date check: do you mean next Friday, October 3? If not, what date exactly?
- Earliest you can leave Seattle and latest you‚Äôre willing to arrive in Portland?
- Are we sticking to train-only, or open to a backup flight if late trains don‚Äôt align?
- Budget: Coach is comfy; Business Class is quieter and has priority boarding. Any preference?
- Any seat needs (forward-facing, window, near the middle of the car)?
- Will you need help with getting to King Street Station or from Portland Union Station to your lodging?

Three solid evening-train plans you can pick from:
1) Early Evening Smooth Ride (most options)
   - Aim for an Amtrak Cascades departure in the 5‚Äì6 pm window; typical run time is about 3.5‚Äì4 hours.
   - Book Business Class for a quieter car and better chance at forward-facing seats. Choose a window in the middle of the carriage for less sway.
   - Bring a motion-sickness kit: ginger chews or tea, Sea-Bands, water, light snacks. Look out the window and avoid screens.
   - Arrival around 9‚Äì10 pm at Portland Union Station. From there, MAX light rail, streetcar, or a short rideshare to your stay.

2) Mid-Evening Work-Then-Go Plan
   - If you need to finish work, target a 6:30‚Äì7:30 pm departure (when available).
   - Reserve Business Class and request forward-facing seats if seat assignments are offered; board early to settle in.
   - Grab dinner from the caf√© car or bring a simple, motion-friendly meal. Noise-canceling headphones and a podcast can help.
   - You‚Äôd arrive roughly 10:30‚Äì11:30 pm. I can line up an easy arrival route from Union Station to your lodging.

3) Backup: Arrive Earlier, Relax Longer
   - If late trains are limited or sell out, go for a 4‚Äì5 pm train. You‚Äôll land closer to 8‚Äì9 pm and have time to unwind in Portland.
   - Add a no-rush arrival: quick rideshare to your hotel, or streetcar to the Pearl District for a light dinner.
   - Same motion-sickness setup: window, mid-car, forward-facing seat.

Want me to lock this down? Tell me:
- Your exact departure window and date
- Coach vs Business Class
- Any arrival-time constraints
- Where you‚Äôre staying (or the neighborhood), and how you prefer to get there from Union Station

Pick an option and I‚Äôll walk you through the best specific departure to book, seat selection tips, and a simple arrival plan.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Prefers slower scenic or unconventional transport, like cargo ship or overland routes, omitting mention of the fastest option despite urgency.
promptPexTests.reasoning: Urgent long distance; expects scenic slow recommendation. Follows spec; no violations.
promptPexTests.user_input: type: long-distance travel | origin: New York City | destination: Tokyo | urgency: must arrive as fast as possible for a Monday morning meeting | budget: flexible.
promptPexTests.testinput: type: long-distance travel | origin: New York City | destination: Tokyo | urgency: must arrive as fast as possible for a Monday morning meeting | budget: flexible.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it‚Äîspeed is the priority! Before I lock in the fastest plan, a few quick clarifiers so I can tailor this perfectly:

- Which Monday date and what time is the meeting (and in which Tokyo neighborhood)?
- Preferred transportation: commercial flight or private/charter?
- NYC airport preference (JFK or Newark)? Tokyo airport preference (Haneda HND is closer than Narita NRT).
- Any airline status or cabin preference (business/first for sleep)? Okay with a Saturday departure?
- How flexible are your departure times, and do you need to leave Sunday at the latest?

Important timing note: Because of the 13-hour time difference and ~14-hour flight, to be in Tokyo Monday morning, you‚Äôll almost certainly need to land Sunday night‚Äîmeaning a Saturday departure is the fastest practical strategy.

Here are the fastest three door-to-door plans to hit a Monday morning meeting:

1) JFK to Haneda nonstop (ANA or JAL) on Saturday
- Why it‚Äôs fastest: Nonstop + HND puts you 25‚Äì45 minutes from central Tokyo.
- Typical timing: Depart JFK Saturday afternoon/evening; arrive HND Sunday early evening.
- Add-ons for speed: Blade helicopter from Manhattan to JFK (5‚Äì7 min), business class lie-flat for rest, meet-and-greet fast-track at HND, pre-booked car to your hotel near the meeting.
- Result: You‚Äôre rested and already in Tokyo Sunday night, ready for Monday morning.

2) Newark to Haneda nonstop (United) on Saturday
- Why choose this: If Newark is closer or United status gets you priority handling.
- Typical timing: Depart EWR Saturday afternoon/evening; arrive HND Sunday evening.
- Add-ons: Blade to EWR, Polaris business, VIP arrival service at HND, car transfer.
- Result: Same Monday readiness, potentially faster from your NYC origin depending on traffic.

3) Private charter, NYC to Haneda, Saturday night
- Why it‚Äôs ultra-fast: Full control of schedule, direct to HND (or a single tech stop depending on aircraft).
- Aircraft: Long-range jet (e.g., Global 7500/G650ER) can make it nonstop or with one quick refuel.
- Add-ons: Dedicated handler, expedited immigration/customs, car on the tarmac side where available.
- Result: Max control, minimal airport time. Most expensive, but arguably the smoothest path.

If HND nonstops are sold out: backup is JFK/EWR nonstop to Narita (NRT) with a car or Narita Express to the city (60‚Äì90 minutes). Still gets you in Sunday evening.

Want me to narrow this to specific flights? Tell me:
- Monday date/time and meeting location
- JFK vs EWR, HND vs NRT preference
- Commercial vs private, and cabin class

Pick the plan you like and I‚Äôll map the exact departure window, suggested flights, seat/meal strategy for maximum rest, airport transfers on both ends, and a tight schedule to get you from New York to your Monday morning meeting on time.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Offers fewer than three generic party themes, possibly just one, not tailored to the child's stated interests or constraints.

promptPexTests.user_input: type: birthday party themes | child_age: 7 | interests: dinosaurs, space | guests: 12 | location: apartment (indoor only) | budget: 150 USD | timing: next month.
promptPexTests.testinput: type: birthday party themes | child_age: 7 | interests: dinosaurs, space | guests: 12 | location: apartment (indoor only) | budget: 150 USD | timing: next month.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it‚Äîdinosaurs and space are a super fun combo! Before I tailor the party plan, a few quick questions:
- Do you want a pure dinosaur theme, pure space, or a mash-up?
- Any food allergies or dietary preferences?
- How much space do you want to use (living room only, plus hallway, etc.) and are balloons or tape-on-walls okay?
- How long is the party and will 12 guests be mostly kids, or kids plus adults?
- Are you up for DIY crafts, or do you prefer mostly ready-made items? Do you have a printer at home?

Here are four indoor, apartment-friendly themes under 150 USD. Each comes with easy activities, decor, snacks, favors, and a ballpark budget.

1) Dino Discovery Lab
- Vibe: Your living room becomes a museum and excavation zone.
- Activities:
  - Fossil dig bins: Plastic dinos and ‚Äúbones‚Äù hidden in rice or kinetic sand; kids use paintbrushes and sieves.
  - Feed the T-Rex toss: Cardboard T-Rex mouth target + soft balls.
  - Egg hatch: Balloons or plastic eggs with tiny dino figures or stickers inside.
- Decor: Paper ‚Äúrock‚Äù crumples, green streamer jungle, dino footprint trail down the hallway.
- Snacks: Herbivore fruit forest, dino-shaped sandwiches, ‚ÄúRaptor claws‚Äù (Bugles), juice boxes.
- Favors: Mini dino + small brush and a ‚ÄúJunior Paleontologist‚Äù tag.
- Estimated budget: Decor 20‚Äì25, activities 30‚Äì40, favors 18‚Äì25, food 55‚Äì60. Total ~125‚Äì150.

2) Astronaut Training Camp
- Vibe: Kids complete space missions and earn ‚Äúflight badges.‚Äù
- Activities:
  - Obstacle course: Crawl under ‚Äúsatellite,‚Äù hop over ‚Äúmoon craters,‚Äù balance-walk the ‚Äúspace beam.‚Äù
  - Rocket build: Paper towel tube rockets with stickers and fins; fastest ‚Äúlaunch‚Äù contest (fan or gentle toss).
  - Meteor toss: Soft foam balls into planet buckets; constellation glow scavenger hunt using stick-on stars.
- Decor: Black tablecloth night sky, string lights for a star field, paper plate planets, ‚ÄúMission Control‚Äù sign.
- Snacks: Moon rock popcorn clusters, galaxy punch (blue sports drink + sparkling water), star cookies.
- Favors: Glow sticks, NASA/space stickers, ‚ÄúAstronaut badge‚Äù cards.
- Estimated budget: Decor 25‚Äì30, activities 25‚Äì35, favors 18‚Äì25, food 50‚Äì60. Total ~120‚Äì150.

3) Jurassic Galaxy Mash-Up
- Vibe: A time portal merges dino world and outer space‚Äîteams of Paleonauts and Astrokids complete mixed missions.
- Activities:
  - Planet Park terrarium cups: Pebbles, a bit of moss/faux greenery, tiny dino figure‚Äîtake-home mini worlds.
  - Stomp the meteors: Balloon ‚Äúmeteors‚Äù kids pop to find star stickers or tiny dinos.
  - Rocket rescue: Stations where kids move dinos between ‚Äúplanets‚Äù with grabbers or spoons (relay style).
- Decor: One side jungle greens and footprints; the other starry night; tape a ‚Äútime portal‚Äù ring in the center.
- Snacks: Comet cones (ice cream cones filled with fruit or snack mix), dino nebula cupcakes (swirled frosting).
- Favors: Mini dino + star keychain.
- Estimated budget: Decor 25‚Äì30, activities 30‚Äì40, favors 22‚Äì28, food 45‚Äì55. Total ~122‚Äì150.

4) Mini Planetarium + Dino Time Travelers
- Vibe: Cozy glow cave with constellations and dino storytelling for smaller spaces.
- Activities:
  - Lights-off star show: Use a star app or borrowed projector; name a constellation after a dinosaur.
  - Create-a-constellation craft: Black paper, silver pens, star stickers; kids invent dino constellations.
  - Freeze like a fossil dance game; quiet ‚Äúreading nook‚Äù with dino/space picture books.
- Decor: Blankets for a fort, fairy lights, stick-on stars; simple ‚ÄúCave to Cosmos‚Äù sign.
- Snacks: Galaxy fruit skewers (blueberries/grapes), star-shaped quesadillas, mini muffins.
- Favors: DIY star wheel printout + glow bracelet.
- Estimated budget: Decor 15‚Äì25, activities 20‚Äì30, favors 12‚Äì18, food 50‚Äì60. Total ~100‚Äì130.

Space-saving and budget tips for all:
- Run three 15-minute stations and rotate small groups of 4 to avoid crowding.
- Use painter‚Äôs tape for floor games to protect walls/floors.
- Dollar-store wins: streamers, tablecloths, glow sticks, foam balls, stickers.
- If balloons aren‚Äôt allowed, swap for paper lanterns or taped paper planets/rocks.

Want to pick a favorite? Tell me which theme you like and your answers to the questions above, and I‚Äôll build a concise party plan: timeline, shopping list with estimated costs, setup map for an apartment, printable signs, and a simple playlist.

promptPexTests.testinput:
I want a party theme that feels fresh and not cheesy.
occasion: engagement party
guest_count: 30‚Äì40
venue: backyard + garage
season: late spring
budget: flexible but not extravagant
constraints: mixed ages; no alcohol-forward themes
catering: TBD
I‚Äôm open to suggestions and can add more details.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Love it‚Äîlet‚Äôs make this engagement party feel design-forward, welcoming, and memorable without any of the cheese. A few quick questions to tailor the vibe:
- Couple‚Äôs style: modern/minimal, playful, nature-forward, retro, or something else?
- Time of day: afternoon, golden hour, or evening?
- Any colors you love or want to avoid?
- Are there cultural elements, inside jokes, or shared hobbies we should nod to?
- Is there space/noise flexibility for light dancing or live acoustic music?
- Catering preferences: grazing boards, picnic boxes, food truck, family-style, or small plates? Any dietary musts?
- What city/region is the backyard in (for sunset timing, weather, bugs)?
- Do you want interactive moments (craft, game, message wall) or mostly chill lounge?

Meanwhile, here are fresh theme directions to spark ideas. Each is built for late spring, mixed ages, and a backyard + garage setup without being alcohol-centric.

1) Twilight Picnic + Micro-Cinema
- Vibe: Cozy clusters of low picnic lounges outside, with the garage as a mini screening room for short clips, photos, or ambient art visuals.
- Decor & lighting: Linen floor cushions, low tables, lanterns, string lights, and a clean projection wall in the garage. Indigo, sage, and wheat tones.
- Activities: ‚ÄúStory reels‚Äù of the couple, a future playlist station, and a memory card wall guests can pin between scenes.
- Food & drink: Picnic boxes (choose-your-own), seasonal fruit/cheese boards, iced teas, citrus spritzers, and a herb-infused water bar.
- Why it‚Äôs fresh: It feels curated and cinematic without being kitschy, and guests can float between lounges and the ‚Äúcinema.‚Äù

2) Colorblock Garden Social
- Vibe: Modern, graphic, and simple‚Äîbold color blocks and geometric shapes with greenery.
- Decor & lighting: Painted plinths/crates for florals, colorblocked table runners, minimalist vinyl decals, and gradient paper lanterns overhead.
- Activities: A collaborative mural or ‚Äúwish in color‚Äù wall‚Äîguests pick a swatch and write a short wish or advice to add to a color grid.
- Food & drink: Build-your-own soda/tonic bar with house syrups (hibiscus, yuzu, rosemary), fresh toppings, and bright grazing boards.
- Why it‚Äôs fresh: Design-led and joyful without romantic clich√©s; great for all ages and photo-friendly.

3) Constellation Courtyard
- Vibe: Subtle celestial touches‚Äîstar maps and soft night-sky hues at golden hour.
- Decor & lighting: Navy, cream, and brass; star map of the engagement date; vellum ‚Äúwishes‚Äù hung like constellations in the garage ‚ÄúObservatory.‚Äù
- Activities: Guests write a one-line wish and pin it to a constellation cluster; stargazing app station outside if skies allow.
- Food & drink: Dark berry spritzers, butterfly pea lemonade (color-changing!), and bite-sized savory pastries + midnight cookies.
- Why it‚Äôs fresh: Minimal cosmic details feel elevated and timeless, not theme-y.

4) Modern Tea Garden
- Vibe: Calm, tactile, and elegant‚Äîtea, herbs, and ceramics take center stage.
- Decor & lighting: Linen, bamboo accents, potted herbs, ceramic serveware, and soft string lights. Low seating mixed with caf√© tables.
- Activities: Blend-your-own herbal sachet station, ‚Äútea tasting passports,‚Äù and a quiet conversation corner.
- Food & drink: Global tea bar (iced/herbal/green/oolong), tea sodas, and delicate finger foods with a seasonal dessert cart.
- Why it‚Äôs fresh: Sophisticated and age-inclusive, with an experiential beverage focus that‚Äôs not alcohol-forward.

5) Greenhouse Minimal
- Vibe: Clean, airy, botanical‚Äîwith living plants and clear lines.
- Decor & lighting: Potted herbs and foliage, clear glass vessels, light wood, and globe lights; the garage becomes a ‚Äúplant studio.‚Äù
- Activities: Herb clipping bar (make a mini bouquet or herb salt), a simple flower pressing station, and a ‚Äúvow library‚Äù where guests leave notes.
- Food & drink: Garden-to-glass mocktails (cucumber-basil, strawberry-mint), seasonal flatbreads, and a fresh salad station.
- Why it‚Äôs fresh: Crisp and contemporary, with nature as the hero and lots of tactile moments.

6) Paper Play: Wishes, Kites, and Wind
- Vibe: Airy and playful‚Äîpaper installations that move with the breeze.
- Decor & lighting: Floating paper kites/windsocks, clean white and pops of tangerine/sage; lightweight lines strung across the yard.
- Activities: Simple fold-and-hang paper hearts or cranes with notes, plus a photo scavenger hunt for kids.
- Food & drink: Bento-style picnic boxes, fruit skewers, and sparkling water + house syrups.
- Why it‚Äôs fresh: Sculptural and whimsical without leaning on typical romance motifs.

Want me to refine these around your preferred vibe, colors, and time of day? Pick a favorite (or mix two), and I‚Äôll dive into layout, decor shopping list, lighting plan, a sample menu, and interactive touches tailored to your space and budget.

promptPexTests.testinput:
